>So perhaps it is only *some* waterski bikes on which one countersteers...
A Sea Doo is a boat. It turns by changing the angle of the duct behind the
propeller. A waterski bike looks like a motorcycle but has a ski where each
wheel should be. Its handlebars are connected through a familiar looking
steering head to the front ski. It handles like a motorcycle.

rec.sport.baseball;From: maynard@ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca (Roger Maynard)
>|> has shown us that he has what it takes to play on a WS winning club.
>What *does* it take to play on a WS winning club?
We have no way of knowing because we cannot separate Morris' contribu-
tion  from the rest of the team's.  There is only one way of determin-
ing best in baseball.  And that is by looking at the  scoreboard  at
the  end  of  the game.  Each game determines which *team* is the best
that day.  At the end of the season
column2: the team that was  the  best  the

column1: most  often  is  the best in the division.  The playoffs determine the
best of the best.  But the point is that the only decision making pro-
cess  used to determine the best is the score of the game and it re-
lates to the *teams*.  Not the individual players.  There is no method
inherent  in  baseball of comparing individual performances.  And that
To say that one player is better than another is to be able to say ab-
solutely  that  player A's team would have played better with player B
in their lineup.  Sheer speculation.  Impossible to ascertain.
If you want to select a group of statistics and claim that Clemens has
done  better  with those statistics as a criteria
have  to  be  able  to  prove  that  those  statistics   measure   the
individual's  contribution  to  winning  the WS - because  that is the
only measure of best that has any meaning in the  context  of  base-
ball.   So  until you can prove that Clemens contributes to a WS cham-
pionship more than Morris your evaluation of  Clemens is totally  sub-
jective  and  is  mere opinion.  I have yet to see that any of you can
predict a WS winner with any greater accuracy than Jeanne Dixon.
>The fact is that Morris didn't win any ballgames
>spite of Morris' contribution.   This has been explained to you
Exactly.  The Jays won with Morris pitching.   And  Boston  wins  with
Clemens pitching.  I am not saying that Morris is better than Clemens.
I am saying that individual comparisons between  players  are  totally
meaningless  and  that anyone claiming that Clemens is better based on
his ERA has missed the point of what baseball is all about.

column2: many times and you are either too stupid or too stubborn to grasp it.

>You are completely consumed by the post hoc
For you to say that means that you have either missed the entire point

column2: or you yourself have committed a fallacy - Ignoratio

he   has  more   rings   (although  I  have
that in the past).  I am saying that it is impossible to  isolate   an
individual's  performance   from that of his team's for the purpose of
comparing that individual's performance with another individual's per-
The stats are a nice hobby and  that's  about  it.  There  is  no  new
knowledge being produced.  So when a poster claims that Morris is better
than Clemens because he has more rings
column2: the poster is no more nor less

>>F350 truck?  This is a 4x4 with leaf springs front and rear.

column2: with a big socket and an air wrench and a floor jack (and a

column1: >>hydrolic bottle jack ...) can I do this at home?
I found that I needed some smaller sockets to undo the shocks.
And a can of WD40 helped...
The sockets needed were metric (exact fit) but I was able to use
some SAE sockets...  13/16 and 15/16 are rather close to 21 and 24mm...
It CAN be fun having a Canadian Ford ...
>>I'm pictureing this:  Undo U bolts.  Put a bottle jack on the axle
>>and raise the bed/frame to take stress off of the leaf spring.  Undo
>>the end bolts/bushings.  Drop the spring.  Turn the bottom leaf.
Didn't have to undo the end bolts/bushings.  Just the 2 U bolts on
each side and the shock absorber.  Jacking up the frame some more
(had to put the spare tire on the garage floor and put a wooden
platform on top of that to get the 'floor jack' high enough to
raise the frame ... I't one TALLL truck...) lifted the spring
free of the axel.  Taking out the block gave me enough room to
undo the pin holding the spring pack together.
The spring pack was held together with a nut on top and a round head
on the other end....  No wrench head...  Vice Grips worked fine...
I soaked the nut with WD40 and it came right off.
Flipped the bottom spring and then...
>>Is this a nightmare waiting to happen

column2: it's easier than doing a decent trigger job on a 1911A1 :-)

column1: I donno ... I'm a little more sore today than after working on a
A 1.5 foot pipe cheater was a real help.  Torque spec for the U bolt
nuts is 150 to 200 ft-lbs (!).   A 1911-A1 doesn't have that kind of
It was a 'challenge' to get the 'pack bolt' back in the spring pack.
with fourth while picking up wrench and vice grips with fifth
and sixth hands ...  I used some string to tie the pack together
while holding the pin in for alignment... then I could let go
Getting the pin back lined up with the lift block was a challenge too...
until I discovered that the axel had 1) Tilted and/or 2) rolled forward.

column2: a bottle jack under the front of the differential

column1: tilted it back in line enough for the pin head to drop into the right

column2: I had to wrestle the wheel into rolling

column1: forward about 1/2 inch to get things to line up.  Spent more than an
hour working on getting the pin head into the hole in the lift block
with levers and ropes and impliments of distruction before I took a
break and thought about WHY it wasn't lined up anymore (since it HAD

column2: axle no longer constrained not to move ... hmmm
it was all much easier to 'close up'.

column3: but not quite as soft as I was hoping for.

column1: At least it now sits level..

column2: I recommend 500cc's or less. And a bike short enough to get

column1: both feet on the ground when you stop.
The one piece of advice EVERYONE will give you is to take a Motorcycle Safety
Foundation Rider's Course. See a dealer for details. In some states
of such a course can give you a break on insurance. It will also teach you
to ride properly from the beginning

column2: here's a goddamn mystery for ya !

column1: Today I was turning a 90 degree corner just like on any other day
was a slight difference-  a rough spot right in my path caused the suspension
to compress in mid corner and some part of the bike hit the ground with a very
tangible thunk.  I pulled over at first opportunity to sus out the damage.
My bike is a Kawasaki GPX250R with footpegs that are hinged and sprung such
that they fold upward and backward on contact with ground etc.
lower extreme corner of each peg there is mounted a bank-follower
little stud that theoretically is the first bit to hit the ground in a
100%-banked turn.  The stud is mounted on the footpeg by a threaded bit about 7

column2: which screws into a threaded hole in the footpeg.  Now for the

column1: The stud on the side of the bike that clunked when I turned was absent.  I'm
fairly sure it was there before the event.  There was no damage to the end of
the footpeg where the stud would ordinarily have been.  In fact
the hole in the footpeg was perfectly intact
having been forcefully ripped out of it only moments previously.

column2: how the f**k do you explain this ?  How can you

column1: rip a tightly fitting steel thread out of a threaded hole (in alloy) without
damaging the thread in the hole ?  Is this some sort of hi-tech design thingo

column2: like that the end of the footpeg suddenly
to let the stud rip out
column3: then changes back to a solid

column1: ?  I'm quite amazed at how this could have happened.  In the meantime

rec.motorcycles;From: thompson@apple.com (Paul Thompson)
>hear screeching tires.  I dart my eyes to my mirrors and realize it's the

column2: in my panic I pop my clutch and stall the

column1: >bike.  Luckily the guy stops a foot behind my rear wheel.
>I understand why you theoretically stop so far behind a car but can you
>really in actuality avoid such an incident?  Suggestions?
The experience you describe is why I don't like to sit with my bike in
gear - I figure there's a chance that I'll be startled in some way and
stall my bike.  And I figure this is more likely than the chance that
I'll be unable to escape some situation because of the extra time
needed to put the bike in gear.
So I concentrate on avoiding situations rather than making split-second
evasive manuvers.  I split lanes so I'm not at the end of the line.
(Unfortunately this is not legal in most of the country)  If I can't
split (perhaps there isn't room) then I will stop near one side of the
lane so I have an easy escape
column2: and leave my bike in gear until the next

column1: car has stopped.  I watch in my mirrors in the mean time to make sure
it will!  Whether I really would have time to move should a car fail to

column2: I haven't had to find out yet.  Some cars have an annoying habbit

column1: of racing up behind you before braking heavilly
column2: so it can be hard to

column1: tell if they are planning to brake or not!

column2: position yourself for an easy exit

A while back I asked for help in defending a traffic ticket I received.
The ticket was for not stopping at a stop sign. Given the conditions
I could not stop in time and decided instead of sliding right through the

column2: I would complete my right-turn and avoid a possible accident.

column1: A police cruiser happened to be approaching the intersection from my left
The officer said The only reason that you even slowed down in the first
place was that you saw me approaching
column2: otherwise you would have bombed right

column1: I would like to thank all those who responded favorably to my request for
help. To all of those who told me to bite the bullet and pay the fine:
The judge sided with me and decided that in this case Not stopping was the
safest thing to do and found me NOT GUILTY.
The officer's statement and my account of the conditions at the time (very

column2: backed by newpaper weather conditions) were the factors what made

column1: the judge decide on his verdict.
Moral: If you have never been to court before and you think you have a case
go for it. It is a very interesting process

column2: here's some additional insight and some theories

column1: >about splitfire plugs and how they boost us as oppossed to cages.
>Splitfires were originally made to burn fuel more efficiently and
>Now I don't know about all of this (and I'm trying to catch up with

column2: but Splitfires should help twins more than

column1: Splitfires work mainly by providing a more-or-less unshrouded spark to the
combustion chamber. If an engine's cylinder head design can benefit from this
then the splitfires will yield a slight performance increase
in lower rpm range torque. Splitfires didn't do diddly-squat for my 1992 GMC
pickup (4.3l V6) but do give a noticeable performance boost in my 1991 Harley
Sportster 1200 and my best friend's 1986 Sportster 883. Folks I know who've
tried them in 1340 Evo motors can't tell any performance boost over plain
plugs (which is interesting since the XLH and big twin EVO combustion chambers
are pretty much the same shape
column2: just different sizes). Two of my friends who

column1: have shovelhead Harleys swear by the splitfires but if I had a shovelhead
I'd dual-plug it instead since they respond well enough to dual plugs to make
the machine work and extra ignition system worth the expense (plus they look
really cool with a spark plug on each side of each head)
Std disclaimer: My opinions are mine

>One thing that gives an automatic an advantage at launch is the fact that
>it has a torque converter vs a clutch.  I know this sounds strange but
>a torque converter multiplies the engine output when launching.  It functions
>as a sort of limited Continuously Variable Transmission. Typically you get
>a torque multiplication of 2 to 3 times depending on the stall speed.
I have yet to see a torque multiplier installed on a production automobile.

column2: but none are presently installed in production autos

column1: that I am aware of.  These are commonly called viscous drive CVTs or
>Contrasted to a clutch which merely slips when feathered (result is no TQ mult)
What the convertor _does_ allow is for the engine to be closer to its
torque peak during the launch before a clutched car can fully engage it's
driveline.  Chevy proved it many years ago with the '70 Camaro (ETs and
terminal 1/4 mile times were close enough tpo be identical for 4 speed and
auto cars).  Note that this is also the major reason that an auto car can
get away with fewer gears than a manual

MK48T02 from thomsom.  It has a timekeeper (clock) and 512 bytes of NVRAM which
has a lithium battery backup.  The battery has a life of ~10 years of poweroff
operation.  Installed in a car it could be left powered on continuously and not
draw much current.  The battery would only be used when your auto battery was

> things are fine.  However I feel like that I dont have the grip of the
> road and feel as if the car is wandering esp. on turns.  Any help
Two shots at it: (1) Check the tires again - if you can see the wear bars
you're down to problem area (and some tires pass a penny test between the
bars - that's no guide at all). Your problem in the wet is call hydroplaning.
You may not have enough tread left to channel water out from under the
tire - so it goes fishy on you as it lifts off the road.

column2: soft tire compounds get harder as you put

column1: them thru more heat cycles. Harder compounds don't grip as well as
soft ones. Effect is very noticable on tires that get very hot very

rec.autos;From: mark@wdcwdc.sps.mot.com (Mark Shaw)
|> |> I heard the diesels are considered cleaner-burning than
|> |> gas engines because the emit less of: Carbon Monoxide
|> |> But they can put out a lot of particulate matter.  I heard
|> |> something about legislation being discussed to clean up
|> |> diesel emissions.  Is there anything in the works to
|> |> install scrubbers for diesels?  How about the feasibility
|> |> of installing them on trucks and cars?  Would it be any
|> |> different than a catylitic converter?  I'd assume easier
|> |> since we're removing particulate matter instead of converting
|> This really bugs me.  The emissions of diesels are the cleanest of any vechicle
|> but they are considered so polluting that they are banned in passenger cars
|> in California.  What a bunch of crap.  Diesel is the fuel of choice for
|> enviromental benefit in Europe while here it's illegal for the same reason.
|> The particulates are nothing but carbon.  They are just an annoyance at worst.
|> Nothing beats the diesel cycle for efficiency and emissions
Diesels fall into the same emissions mythology as alcohol fuels.  The main reason
they are considered cleaner is because they are better at the emissions we
actually measure and regulate.  But they also contribute additional emissions
which have long been determined to be as harmful
Current evidence is pointing to most visible smog actually being diesel emissions
and suspended particles and less of a photo-chemical reaction.  Diesel particulates
are now becoming a major concern in decreased lung capacity.  And alcohols emit
signifcantly more aldehydes (a known carcinigen) than gasoline.  The evidence
is mounting that while we have been beating the gasoline engine to death
have been ignoring the effects of the alternatives.
And anyone who thinks diesels are so great
column2: should go and spend a few hours in

column1: rush hour traffic in some cities in Europe.  There the stench of the diesels is
awful and it can even burn the eyes.
Diesels being clean is only relative to our current standards.

>I understand why you theoretically stop so far behind a car but can you

If you had been looking in your mirror
column2: you would have seen the guy coming

column1: before you heard the screeching tires.
When you're stopped at a light:
1)  Stop so that you're got space in front of you
decides they want to plow into you.
2)  Keep the bike in first with the clutch in until at least a couple of cars

column2: so you don't have to waste a second you don't have

column1: trying to get it in gear if you need to move.
3)  Watch your mirrors.  In that situation
column2: most of the hazards you are

column1: trying to avoid are coming from behind you.  SIPDE (<-- msf-geek-speak)
isn't just for when you're moving.  And you're less likely to panic and stall
the bike if you've got time to prepare before the guy's tires lock up behind
you.  (You still get the bejeezus scared out of you
of quickly-rising dread than a sudden jolt.)

*      ATTENTION ALL FOUR WHEEL OFF ROAD ENTHUSIASTS       *

column2: a Chicago land four wheel drive club

column1: sponsoring an On/Off Road Rally Sunday April 25th.
* For those who ask What is an on/off road rally?
An On/Off Road Rally consists of the following:
1. An on-the-road rally where participants are given a set of
directions and clues guiding participates around the
Joliet/Plainfield area.  The object is to navigate a course
based on a set of directions and clues.  Participants will
be given a set of questions pertaining to the course which
they must answer along the way.  Points are awarded for the
number of correct answers given.  Directions will ultimately
lead to an off-road area where a four-wheel drive course is
set-up.  At various locations in the on-road course
will be set-up where participants will be asked other questions
or requested to perform some activity (e.g. tire roll

column2: four wheel drive course where participants

column1: Points are awarded for successfully navigating off-road obstacles
without getting stuck.  If you should get stuck (which is half

column2: there will be assistance to get your vehicle

column1: unstuck so you can try it again.  The off-road course will
divided up based on tire size
column2: so stock 4x4s as well as modified

column1: At the end of the rally
column2: trophies will be awarded to top scoring

column1: participants.  Door prizes and dash plaques will also be given out.
Food and drinks also available at the conclusion.
* This is an organized activity sponsored by the Joliet Mud Turtles
so safety and fun is our foremost concern.  All 4x4s must be
street legal and have solid tow points for the off-road section
of the course - we don't want to have to separate someone's bumper
* Registration is between 9 and 10:30 a.m.  First truck out at 10:00 a.m.
* There is an entry fee of $10 per truck.
* You must have a co-driver (passengers allowed)
* A valid drivers license is required

but Yammie has a TM on the name. The Hawk is a purer 'twin spar'
frame design: investment castings at steering head and swing arm
tied together with aluminum extruded beams. The Yammie solution is

I can't think of another subject that generates as much contradictory
advice as traffic laws and their enforcement.  Everybody's got an
opinion and is dead certain they are right.  Yet acurate information is
extremely difficult to come by.  The DMV doesn't know.  Cops don't
know.  Your traffic school instructor doesn't know.  The vehicle code
only tells part of the story.  Judges choose to interpret the laws in a
wide variety of ways.  And the public at large?  I seldom hear any
advice that doesn't disagree with something I've experienced.
If you don't believe me I suggest you get a copy of the vehicle code

column2: and then sit in on a day or two of court and see what really

column1: happens.  Read Fight Your Ticket too
section at the end where it says your chances are lousy and you're

column1: California.  I've carefully prepared for court
revealing serious holes in the officer's story
the maximum allowable fine (plus assessments of over 100%) - the
message clear that the judge does not appreciate John Q Public trying
So here's my advice when you find yourself with a ticket:  Take traffic
school if you can.  If it's a serious matter get a lawyer.  A lawyer
can present the exact same case as you

column2: I thought I'd check net.wisdom on the

column1: It's a 1985 Buick Skyhawk (I know...I know)
When I drive tha car long enough to get it hot (especially at
highways speeds) the transmission has this nasty habit of
getting stuck in 3rd gear.  As a result
a light the motor stalls.  Putting the car in park
for 30-60 seconds before restarting sometimes allows the transmission
to reset and go back into 1st.  Otherwise
My thoughts:  Either it the 3rd gear band is binding and getting
stuck when it gets hot (not so likely) or perhaps the lock-up
converter is not disengaging properly (seems likely).  The least
likely (keeping fingers crossed) is that some critical vacuum
hose has broken/cracked and this behaviour is due to lack of
vaccuum somewhere (as used to happen with old modulator valves).
My background is that my father owns a service station and
I worked there on and off from 10-19 years of age.  Please
feel free to be as technical as you want. :)
I'd appreciate hearing any tips/suggestions/offers of free

having problem with stadium management (the City did not own Yankee
Stadium until 1972).  The idea was to get the Giants to move into Shea.
When a deal was worked out between the Giants and the Yankees the
the new stadium.  The Titans were playing in Downing Stadium (where the

rec.motorcycles;From: stefan@prague (Stefan Fielding-Isaacs)
devoted to racing and racing-related topics. This is a pretty broad
interest group. Individuals have a variety of backgrounds: motojournalism
roadracing from the perspective of pit crew and racers
The size of the list grows weekly. We are currently at a little
over one hundred and eighty-five members
The list was formed (October 1991) in response to a perceived need
to both provide technical discussion of riding at the edge of
performance (roadracing) and to improve on the very low signal-to-noise
ratio found in rec.motorcycles. Anyone is free to join.
Discussion is necessarily limited by the rules of the list to
issues related to racing motorcycles and is to be flame-free.
HOW TO GET THE DAILY DISTRIBUTION
You are welcome to subscribe. To subscribe send your request to:
Traffic currently runs between five and twenty-five messages per day
NB: Please do _not_ send your subscription request to the
After you have contacted the list administrator
an RSVP request. Please respond to this request in a timely manner
so that you can be added to the list. The request is generated in
order to insure that there is a valid mail pathway to your site.

column2: you will be added to either the daily

column1: or digest distribution (as per your initial request).
HOW TO GET THE DIGEST DISTRIBUTION
It is possible to receive the list in 'digest'ed form (ie. a
single email message). The RoadRacing Digest is mailed out
whenever it contains enough interesting content. Given the
frequency of postings this appears to be about every other
Should you wish to receive the list via digest (once every

column2: please send a subscription request to:

column1: HOW TO POST TO THE LIST
This is an open forum. To post an article to the list
Depending on how mail is set up at your site you may or may
not see the mail that you have posted. If you want to see it
(though this isn't necessarily a guarantee that it went out)
you can include a metoo line in your .mailrc file (on UNIX
Because I haven't had the time (or the inclination to replace
the list distribution mechanism) we still have a problem with
bounces returning to the poster of a message. Occasionally
sites or users go off-line (either leaving their place of
employment prematurely or hardware problems) and you will receive
bounces from the race list. Check the headers carefully
if you find that the bounce originated at Sun (from whence I
administer this list) contact me through my administration
(in body of message write: subscribe euro-moto)

I need some advice on having someone ride pillion with me on my 750 Ninja.
This will be the the first time I've taken anyone for an extended ride
(read: farther than around the block  :-).  We'll be riding some twisty
fairly bumpy roads (the Mines Road-Mt.Hamilton Loop for you SF Bay Areans).
Communication:  work out your own system.  Or just slow down and holler
back every once in a while.  At reasonable speeds

column2: we can hear each other.  It's only above

column1: Balance: New passengers are a real pain
they're going to react to steering.  Some people catch on immediately
and lean with me.  Others are completely skittish about the leaning

column2: and keep their bodies perpendicular to the horizon.  This is a
but manageable.  The WORST are the passengers who stay
then REMEMBER in the middle of a turn

column1: and WHIP AROUND until they're in the `correct' position.  This always
screws up the line I've picked out.
Here's my personal checklist of things to tell passengers:
- Keep feet on pegs at all times
column2: unless I say otherwise.  Do not

column1: get on/off unless I say you can.  (I've had people try to dismount

column2: just as I'm pulling in to a parking space!)

column1: - We get *GOOD* traction.  We're not going to fall over.  (Many
first-time riders are surprised by how tightly you can turn!)
- Turn dynamics:  sit so that you feel like you're sitting upright and
we're going straight.  Trust your butt

column2: close your eyes for a couple of turns to get the feel

column1: of it.  Or just hug me tight.

column2: no sudden moves -- shift your weight as desired

column1: - Your faceplate is yours to open/close as desired.
- Trust is essential.  Trust the driver (me) to do the right
thing -- I've driven many miles on this thing
to operate it.  Enjoy the ride.  (This is important to

column2: one of my first-time passwngers seemed to

column1: watch the speedo like a hawk:  I drove her to the beach down 84
I humored her for a while
column2: then simply covered the speedometer with

column1: the spare piece of duct tape I keep stuck to the top of the cluster.
Problem solved:  she watched the scenery instead of the

column2: and had a much better time.  Based on her

column1: trust my ability to choose a safe speed for the bike.)

and gives the bike a chance to warm up.

While not exactly a service incident
column2: I had a similar experience recently

column1: when I bought a new truck.
I had picked out the vehicle I wanted and after a little haggling we
agreed on a price. I wrote them a check for the down payment plus tax
and license and told them I'd be back that evening to pick up the truck.

column2: I had to wait about an hour before the finance guy could

column1: get to me. When I finally got in there
started adding up the numbers. He then discovered that they had
miscalculated the tax & license by about $150. He then said he needed
another $150 from me. I said we had already agreed on a price and it was

column2: I wasn't giving them any more money. The finance guy then

column1: brought in the manager on duty who proceeded to give me a hard time. I
reminded him that I was the customer and I didn't think I should be
treated like that and that if he didn't back off he could forget the whole
deal. He made some smart remark so I told him where he could stick it
snatched back my check and left. Needless to say
Early the next morning I got a call from the general sales manager wanting
to know what happened. I related the story and he apologised profusely and
asked if there was anything they could do to change my mind. I told him
that if they gave me the truck for free I probably still wouldn't take it
that there were other dealers in town
column2: I was a repeat customer of theirs

column1: and that they should learn how to treat customers
pretty steamed about the whole affair. He gave me the line about hating to
lose a customer and they would try to find a solution

column2: the owner of the dealership called me

column5: and said that they would cover the $150 plus

column1: knock another $400 off the price of the truck. I told him I'd think about
it and he gave me his private
and assured me that they valued me as a customer
I thought about it for a few hours and discussed it with my wife and we

column2: what the hell...that was a pretty decent deal

column1: back and accepted his offer. When I went back the next day to pick up the

column2: I received the royal treatment. Everyone seemed to know about the
even the lot boy. Everything went smoothly and I was out of

column1: there in my new truck in about 30 mins.

column2: I guess I'm a reasonably satisfied customer. However

column1: have happened in the first place. I was a bit shocked to have a sales
person talk to me like that. I don't expect them to bow and grovel
sure don't expect to be given a hard time either

column2: I'm happy with the truck and it turned out to be a couple hundred

column1: dollars under invoice and they paid most of the first year's license fee.
I'm not sure whether I'll go back to that dealer

rec.autos;From: blf@apollo.hp.com (Barry Frishberg)
> Earlier I commented on the Valentine-1 and jimf@centerline.com replied
> about the value of the units bogey counter.  I didn't really go into
> why I called this feature a gimmick so here is more explanation.  Thanks
> Jim for the good comments and opinion.
> From what I understand the Valentine-1 can only tell if these
> microwaves are coming from the front
column2: rear or both.  There are only

column1: > two antennas.  If they are coming from both this in interpreted as a
> side bogey.  Bogey counts are determined as sources by their
> relative strength to one another even if they are reflections of the
It sounds like your analysis is based on hypothesis and not
actually using the Valentine-1.  I'd like to give some feedback based on
real life experince.  I keep the Valentine-1 in advanced logic mode
and it rarely lights up as a Christmas tree.  The only time it does
is when I am in the middle of a major shopping area and then it makes
sense that is does since there are >= 8 sources coming from many different
directions.  I have found the Valentine-1 to be consistent in its
reporting of bogeys regardless of any moving cars in the area.
I have found the directional indication to be very useful.  In one case
there was two radar traps set up within one mile of each other.  As I
the detector was set off again pointing in the forward direction.  With
other radar detectors I would have assumed that this was due to a reflection.
But with the Valentine-1 I knew there was a high probability that there
was another trap.  And there was!

column2: the directional helped discern a false alarm from

column1: changes.  The directional also allows me to focus my attention as to where
the signal might be coming from instead of having to look all over the
place.  When a car is approaching me from the rear with a detector

column2: I can tell that the signal is coming from the rear and as the

column1: car passes me I can verify the source.  With other detectors
have been unable to do this and would have had to assume that there was a radar
I've had the Valentine-1 for several months now and find its added features
to be useful and not gimmicks.

Most helmets lose their protective properties because the inner liner

column2: long before the outer shell is damaged or

column1: delaminates from age.  Dr. Hurt tested helmets for many years
following his landmark study and has estimated that a helmet can lose
up to 80% of it's effectiveness from inner liner compression.  I have
a video he produced that discusses this phenomenon in detail.
Puncture compression of the type caused by mirrors
other relatively sharp objects is the worst offender.  Even when the

column2: dents and holes in the foam can seriously

column1: degrade the effectiveness of a helmet.  If you are in the habit of
parking your lid on the mirrors
column2: I suggest you look under the

column1: comfort liner at the condition of the foam.  If it is significantly

column3: and I'll ride if I want to...

rec.motorcycles;From: karr@cs.cornell.edu (David Karr)
>Hello everyone.  I'm new to motorcycles so no flames please.  I don't
>have my bike yet so I need a few pieces of information:
>[...]  Any stories on how you all learned?
I'll tell you my story as an example of what *not* to do.
Early in 1984 I took some riding lessons from my college roommate on
his old Honda CB360T.  He had taken the MSF beginner's course
actually learned *some* of what I needed to know to ride.
I proceeded to buy a beat-up Honda CL350 for $400 and a $12 helmet and
rode around wearing this and a cotton windbreaker.  Then I decided to
invest in a full-face helmet (first smart move).  Sometime around then
I also passed my road test.

column3: I got caught in a rainstorm on my way home from a

column1: 4-mile trip.  Entering the town where I lived (a rather urban suburb)
I had to stop suddenly for a red light that I noticed too late

column2: and was ejected face upward into the

column1: oncoming lane of traffic.  Fortunately for me the oncoming traffic was
also stopped for the same red light
column2: otherwise I might have slid under

column1: Experienced Rider Course from the MSF and saw that earlier training
could have helped me greatly.  In your case the need is even greater
since you have nobody to help you practice even the most basic stuff
So my advice is to take the MSF beginner's course first thing.  I
wouldn't even buy a bike until you've taken the course
happen to pick up a real good deal and can store it someplace until

column1: poor.  I'd guess DC is more like Boston than like a rural area
>3)  Any recommendations on what I should buy/where I should look for it?
There used to be annual buyer's guides in the usual motorcycle
magazines; I found those helpful in getting an idea of what new or
recent models might be available.  You could probably look through
past issues to size up what used bikes might be available.  (My first
bike was 13 years old when I bought it so I went on my friend's advice
instead.)  Also look at the bikes that you see people riding or that
are parked on the street.  I basically settled on my present bike by
noticing that there were a lot of high-mileage BMW's running around
and they were generally set up the way I wanted.
Nothing wrong with talking to various dealers in your area or visiting
showrooms.  Dealers in the Boston area
column2: at least when I was shopping

column2: although I ended up buying both bikes in private sales.

Which is better - a one-piece Aerostitch or a two-piece Aerostitch?
We're looking for more than Well
What is best? Books have been written on that! But in regard to
AeroStich it really depends on your particular size
If you upper and lower body are not proportional (according to aero
dimensions) then it probably is going to be better mixing and matching
the 2 piece suit. I have the 2 piece suit and I am very happy with it.
Having my life quota of scars from crashing off road
concerned with good protection and I believe that the difference in
protection between the 1 and 2 piece suits is almost negligible. I
think the optional hip pads and back protector make much more of a
difference. One thing that is nice about the 2 piece is if you go
somewhere and then want to walk around for a while (still with jacket)
you can just detach and stow the pants.
One thing to note is that Goldfine has problems getting a good fit for
many women (with standard suits). Supposedly for smaller women (and
petite men for that matter) the 1 piece will fit better.
Another recommendation is to pay for mods if you need them. I wish I
got 2-3 inches added to my pant legs. I find the Long suits are not
really that long (I can't imagine how short the standard suits must

>speed measurement works.  A high frequency microwave (X band approx 10
>GHz and K is approx 24 GHz) is sent out and reflected back to the
>antenna off of an automobile or other objects.  If an object is moving
>a Doppler shift (about 34 Hz per MPH on X Band) occurs
>and converted to miles per hour.  These waves bounce all over the
>place and they can reflect many times and go in many directions.
>From what I understand the Valentine-1 can only tell if these

us bought a 1967 tranny to cart the gear around in.It was in terrible

days cleaning it up and putting in a partition and more seating but 'til

pig shit came flying out the vents!!!.

column2: of course there were no pollution controls

When the mechanical fuel pump quit we put in an electric one from a
Morris Minor that worked great. Ah fond memories.

rec.autos;From: kega@celsiustech.se (Kent Gabrin)

column2: and lord knows wherever else used to drive on

column1: >Australians still do drive on the wrong side of the road. I believe
>Sweden changed in 1968. The way I heard it was that they swapped
>all the traffic signs around one Sunday....
As I live in Sweden I remember the day perfectly well. We changed
side 1967-09-03 (or 03-SEP-1967). I don't remeber the exactly time but
it was in the night. (in the 'big' cities like Stockholm & Gothenburg
weekend.) The day was a Sunday and everything was prepared in before.
Before the day we was told to follow the yellow lines on the road and
after it was the white one that matters. The signs with arrows on was
prepared with a 'left mode' label that was torn off that night to
reveal the new right mode arrow.
The year after Iceland also changed.
About cars: Before the H-day (H as in Hoegertrafik. hoeger is
Swedish and stands for 'right') practically all cars already had their
steering wheels on the left side. Even the imported cars from UK had
the wheel on 'the right side'. At last we have cars with the wheels on
More contries that uses the left side is:
BTW. Some sais that the left side is the right side because Ivanhoe
and other knights meet at the left when they fight in tournaments. :-)

I need some advice on having someone ride pillion with me on my 750 Ninja.
This will be the the first time I've taken anyone for an extended ride
(read: farther than around the block  :-).  We'll be riding some twisty
fairly bumpy roads (the Mines Road-Mt.Hamilton Loop for you SF Bay Areans).
I'd say this is a very bad idea - you should start out with something
much mellower so that neither one of you get in over your head.
That particular road requires full concentration - not the sort of
thing you want to take a passenger on for the first time.
Once you both decide that you like riding together

column2: *then* go for a hard core road
it's *your* (moral) responsibility to make sure that she

column1: I bought a '93 Probe GT with the PEP 263A last July (now at 9500 miles)

My criteria: a fun car with ABS

column2: but checking with insurance people ruled that out.

column1: The Tri-Star cars (Eclipse/Talon/etc) were out since they don't have an air bag.
Ditto for the Mustang(also no ABS).
The SE-R/NX2000/M20 fell into the pocket-rocket category.  A good used car buy.
The MX-6 was almost there but rolled more than I liked.
I didn't like the Prelude dash/instrumentation at all.  Too weird for me.
The MR2 has a much smaller non-passenger space than I needed
The Celica was ok but underpowered when loaded with options (and somewhat
I never considered the 240SX since it didn't have an airbag.  I did look at it
for its RWD virtues but that's it.  The Corolla never entered my mind.
I should have looked at the Mitsubishi VR4/Dodge Stealth more.
The car design is different than earlier years
column2: so it's too early to see its

column1: reliability so far.  For what it's worth
Shutting door with windows up from inside rarely makes good wind seal.
Headlights have stuck up a few times (weather?)
air conditioning broke ~4000 miles (pressure cycling switch)
condensation around rear washer fluid container doesn't drain completely.
crammed engine; little hope for do-it-yourselfers (typical)
parts somewhat more expensive than normal Ford parts
underside plastic doesn't like sharp driveways and speedbumps (typical).
stitched properly.  Hopefully just a fluke.
Ford only gives 1 key with the car.  C'mon Ford
Rear hatch has no padding on corners when up.  I'm waiting for the day when
I bash my head on the corner.
horn buttons behind air bag in spokes and not in center (personal preference)
Tires fling dirt/mud onto side of car
handling (very good for FWD; understeer only at limits)
Very little torque steer at full power (much better than the '90 SHO I drive)
rear seats fold down (I have few rear seat passengers so a trunk not important)
No shake/rattle noises when going over bumps/potholes (still!)
Tires: 225/55VR16 Goodyear Eagles (70% left; hoping for 30K :-)

Summary: My air vents don't work on my 71 Skylark
I have a '71 Buick Skylark with 148K on it.  I bought it in California

column2: I'd like to keep it for another year.  The only problem is these

column1: Indiana winters--my heater controls don't work.
The car has vacuum operated control switches for the vents.  Right now it is
stuck in the vent mode.  It will blow warm air
column2: but I can't switch the air

column1: flow to either the floor (I can live without this) or the defrost (I can't
live without this).  I probably could just jam the air deflector to the

column2: but this blows a lot of air in my face and is

column1: kind of like putting a vacuum cleaner in reverse.
I have taken parts of the dash off and looked at the vacuum system and I think
the problem (or part of it) is with the two diaphragms which control up/down
and outside/inside air flow.  THe diaphragm which controls outside(vent)/in-
side(no vent) air is cracked most of the way around

column2: considering the advanced age of the car.

column1: 1)  Is there anything I should be aware of about this (other than
the fact that I should move from Indiana) ?
2)  In the event that replacement diaphragms aren't available

column1: Q:  Do radar jammers work?  Are they legal?
Detailed answer:  Cheap radar jammers do not work well at all.
Jammers that work are expensive and usually the property of the
military.  Jammers are a major violation of the regulations of the
Federal Communications Commission of the USA.

(PS: While John mentions below that net access and a bike are the only

column2: that's not strictly true these days

column1: there are a number of Denizens who lack one or both.)
There is a group of motorcyclists that gets together and does all the normal
things that a bunch of bikers do.  They discuss motorcycles and
argue with each other and plan rides together.
The difference between this group and your local motorcycle club is that
although they get together just about everyday
other face to face.  The members of this group live all over the known world
and communicate with each other electronically via computer.
The computers range from laptops to multi-million dollar computer centers;
the people range from college and university students to high-tech industry
professionals to public-access electronic bulletin-board users.  Currently
the group's primary on-line meeting place) carries about 2250 articles per
month;  it is read by an estimated 29
posters belong to a motorcycle club
The DoD started when motorcyclist John R. Nickerson wrote a couple of
parodies designed to poke fun at motorcycle stereotypes.  Fellow computer
enthusiast Bruce Robinson posted these articles under the pen name
of Doom.  A while later Chuck Rogers signed off as DoD nr. 0003 Keeper of
the Flame.  Bruce was then designated DoD nr. 0002
The idea of a motorcycle club with no organization

issuing DoD numbers to anyone who wanted one.  To date there have been

column1: almost 400 memberships issued to people all over the United States and
Keeper of the List Sloan eventually designed a club patch.  The initial run
of 300 patches sold out immediately.  The profits from this went to the
American Motorcycle Heritage Foundation.  Another AMHF fund raiser --
selling Denizens of Doom pins to members -- was started by Arnie Skurow a

column2: the project was successful and the profits were

column1: donated to the foundation.  So far
to the AMA museum.  A plaque in the name of the Denizens of Doom now hangs

Motorcycle Club was born. A club in which the majority of members have
never met one another face to face (and perhaps like it that way)
feel that they know one another pretty well (or well enough given some
of the electronic personalities in the newsgroup). A club organized
and run (in the loosest sense of the word) by volunteers through the
network via electronic news and mail
(often used to organize group rides amongst members who live in the

column1: Where will it end? Who knows? Will the DoD start sanctioning races

Will the DoD have a rally in which the attendees demand a terminal

column2: so I don't see weight as too much

column1: My fiancee' and I do quite a bit of sporty riding 2-up.  I'll tell you
what we've found and the systems we've worked out.

column2: accelerate MUCH slower than usual.  It's tough for the rider

column1: to judge how scary fast acceleration is

column2: have her lean forward and at the same angle as you (normally

column1: this means she isn't leaning at all.)  It's very disconcerting to be leaned
over and have your passenger leaning so that they're sitting straight up.
Much balance is lost and this can be dangerous.

column2: do so MUCH slower than usual.  Again

column1: for the rider to judge how scary fast deceleration is
onto something and leaning forward.  However
because braking too fast will shove the passenger forward into you
shoves you into the tank at an inopportune location.

column2: have the passenger keep her knees against you and the bike

column1: out wide.  This helps balance and gives her somegrip.
- When you passenger is in fear
column2: she will squeeze her knees against you.
but what else?  Are there traditional

column1: > signals for SLOW DOWN!! or GO FASTER!! or I HAFTA GO PEE!! etc.???
We only have a couple signals.  Slow down is her either tapping me on

column2: or slapping my helmet with all her might.  Depends on the urgency

column1: Turn here is done by her pointing in the direction of an exit.  This is
also the sign for cool!  Look at that.  I hafta pee is the same sign
as turn here.  I'm hungry is the same sign.  Go faster is usually
done by her jumping up and down on her pegs in glee.  I usually see slow
down more often than go faster.
> I really want this to be a positive experience for us both
> she'll want to go with me again
column2: so any help will be appreciated...

column1: The best thing to do before the ride is to talk to a riding buddy
pillion on his or her bike.  It's incredibly frustrating
you as a rider know what your bike will do
feel you're about to scrape hard parts all the time

column2: or go careening off the edge of a volcanic mountain

column1: Pillioning yourself is good training to take somebody on your pillion pad.

column2: remember that it's much more draining and tiring to ride 2-up
because you're concentrating on much more

column1: in the Zen of the moment less.  Remember this.

Before each Dodger game the public address announcer makes a speech

is a season ticket holder and on his request the Dodgers have relocated

ERA indicates the average number of earned runs attributed to a pitcher per

column2: if a pitcher pitched 3 innings and gave up 1 earned
his 9 inning equivelent perfomance would be 3 earned runs

column1: is 3.00.  To compute the ERA you simply take the number of earned runs divided
by the innings pitched and then multiple the result by 9.
An earned run is run that is given up by the pitcher that is not attributed
to a fielding error.  More specifically
column2: if an error occurs that represented
all runs scored after the error are considered UNEARNED runs.

column1: Earned runs are also runs scored as a result of players who were left on base
when the pitcher exited the game.  Here are some examples:
If there are two outs in an inning and there are men on base.  If
an error occurs that represents the third out
this error and NOT counted as earned runs.
If a pitcher issues some base on balls (walks)

column2: he is responsible for the people who

column1: were left on base.  If the those runners who were left on base score
and the score was not a result of an error
attributed to the pitcher who left the game.
I hope this explains things for you.

column2: if the Infield Fly is *not* caught
column3: at what point can a runner

column1: >legally leave his base w/o fear of being doubled off for advancing too
The runner can leave his base at any time.  If the ball is caught
he's got to tag up.  If it isn't caught
column2: he _doesn't_ have to tag up at

column3: your runner at second can sprint for glory

column1: as soon as the ball is popped up.  If it isn't caught
The only effect the infield fly has is to make the batter out
thereby removing the force on the runners on base.  All other rules apply
as if you were standing second with first open and the ball is popped up.

I have had this happen to me often enough that I always look for it.
On my ride to work in the morning I come to a stop light where there are
3 lanes in my direction.  One for left turns
one for right turns.  All clearly marked.  Plus there is a clearly marked
bicycle lane.  I ride into the right turn lane with my signal on and stop at
the stop line.  Looking left to see if I can make a right turn on red and
when I start to move discovered that some idiot has pulled into the bike
lane and is trying to pass me on the right.  GRRR.
I always do a head check on bike lanes.  Not always for bicycles. . .

rec.autos;From: mboenig@dewey.NMSU.Edu (BOENIG)
Probably the most famous V16 is the one Cadillac made from about 1925
to 1935.  They had to scale down then because the Great Depression really put
the crimp on luxury cars.  It had 452 cubic inches with over two hundred horse
power.  They don't make them like they used to.
There were others though.  Packard had one until about 1930 whe it down

column2: their mainstay for the next twenty years.

column1: Lincoln and Pierce Arrow might have also had one but I am not two sure.
Most luxury and semi-luxury cars of this era at least experimented with
V16 if they did not actually produce them.  There was actually a cylinder war
among the Big Three to see who could produce the biggest engine.

dealer was more reluctant this time to replace it.  But I convinced them to

problem.)  I haven't noticed water in the taillamps (or the trunk) for the last 2.5

and seals.  The guy who bought it had a mechanic pull the valve covers

expect 3 players to be good all 5 years and 3 to be bad every year.
This is what we actually get--
Essentially the distribution of clutch performers by number of years
of good performance is the same as what you would get if the process
leading to deviations from non-clutch performance was completely random.
If there was anything to clutch hitting (at least in this definition)

column2: you expect to see the number of

column1: players at the ends to be much larger than that predicted by flipping

column2: if you limit yourself to players who were a lot above

column1: or below average in clutch situations (say
the mean) more than one year
column2: the random explanation still looks good.

column1: In the four years ('84-'87) that I looked at the data from Elias
were 79 (29) players with a minimum of 25 (50) at bats in clutch
situations that were 1 sigma from the mean two different years.  Of

column2: 38 (14) of them changed sign between the two
they were great clutch hitters one year and

column1: really horrible the other year.  If it was just a random process
you'd expect those numbers to be 39.5 (14.5).
Everything that's been measured about clutch hitting over a period
of years that could be used to predict any ability with any
proposed definition has looked like a random process (with the
caveat that there may be something related to platoon advantage
that could be dragged out of the data--e.g.
probably never had a clutch AB against a left-handed pitcher
but he might well have had some in blowouts
be a bias since his clutch ABs would be more geared to his
platoon advantage).  This is not a subject that has been glanced
at casually.  A lot of people have put a lot of effort into
studying it and every one of them

column2: has been unable to find anything that would allow

column1: you to predict how someone will do in clutch situations better
than flipping a coin.  (Self-serving plug follows:  some of the
flaws in the Elias study are discussed in my paper in the forth-
authors are supposed to get a slice of the advance

column2: I keep track of a category called
defined as a play made that an average fielder would not

column1: make with average effort.  Using the 1992 Defensive Averages posted

column2: I've figured out some defensive stats

column1: for the leftfielders. Hits Stolen have been redefined as Plays Kevin

column2: I realize that's unfair.  Kevin's probably the victim of pitching staff
and a monster park factor.  But let's put it this way:  If we

column1: replaced every leftfielder in the league with someone with Kevin's 49.4% out

column2: how many extra hits would go by?

column1: To try and correlate it to reality a little more

column2: based on the number of outs made compared to what a league

column1: average fielder would make.  By the same method I've calculated Net Extra

column2: I throw all this into a a formula I call Defensive Contribution
it represents the defensive contribution of a player.

column1: I add this number to OPS to get DOPS (Defense + Onbase Plus Slug)
should represent the player's total contribution to the team.  So don't
take it too seriously.  The formula for DCON appears at the end of this
The short version -- definition of terms
HS -- Hits Stolen -- Extra outs compared to Kurt Stillwell
NHS -- Net Hits Stolen -- Extra outs compared to average fielder
NDP -- Net Double Plays -- Extra double plays turned compared to avg fielder
NEB -- Net Extra Bases --  Extra bases prevented compared to avg. fielder
DCON -- Defensive Contribution -- bases and hits prevented
DOPS -- DCON + OPS -- quick & dirty measure of player's total contribution.
Name            HS   NHS   NEB   DCON    DOPS
Name            HS   NHS   NEB   DCON    DOPS
Why such a bizzare formula?  Basically
column2: it's designed to be added into the
with the idea that a run prevented is as important as a run scored.

column1: The extra outs are factored into OBP
column2: while the extra bases removed are

column1: factored into SLG.  That's why I used PA and AB as the divisors.
For more discussion see the post on Hits Stolen -- First Base 1992
It is considered good to look wise
overburdened with information -- J. Golden Kimball

vacuum valve in the fuel petcock. When it is cold
to open the valve just enough to allow gas to the carbs with the choke on
since the choke creates more low pressure in the carbs when on to draw gas
and as the engine and surrounding area warm up

panels off and remove the fuel hose to the carbs. Connect a tube of the

column2: preferably clear tubing to observe fuel flow

>shifting is eaiser/quicker at high rpms (4000-7000). I also skip gears some

For those of you who are thinking about fiamms
column2: you might also want to think

column1: about airhorns. I just installed a set of Bosch air horns ordered from
Dennis Kirk (pg. 282 of the latest catalog) on my '85 FJ1100. They are rated
at 93db at 7 meters. I installed them using 10 gage wire from the battery to
the relay to the compressor to ground. My stock horn connectors fit the relay
pins just fine. I soldered the connections to the relay and compressor
a crimp type battery connector and an inline 10amp fuse/connector from NAPA.
I installed the compressor just forward of the fuse box in the front
fairing by tie wrapping between the steering head frame and the black steel tube
frame used to support the front fairing. You have to remove the front fairing to

column2: but it fits outside of the frame but inside the fairing on the two

column1: vertical supports just in front of the fuses. Depending how tight your fairing

column2: you should be able to fit it somewhere in the fairing.

column1: The compressor is about 2 in diameter and about 5 long.
The relay mounted on the front of the steering head frame (it is small
so there should be plenty of good places for it.
I found a perfect place for the horns that required only tie wraps to
mount. The horns fit inside the front fairing/frame and stick out on either side
just in front of the air scoops
column2: but behind the turn signals. The back of the

column1: horns point back towards the center of the bike and come real close to where
the gas tank connects to the front part of the frame. There is just enough
room to the outside to allow full lock to lock clearance
cut outs in the frame for the back of the horn to go into.
The short horn is even with the fairing
column2: and the long one sticks out
but it is really not that noticable unless you look

column1: closely. They end up pointing down slightly and maybe 30 degrees from straight
ahead (perfect for those cagers trying to change lanes into you).
If you have any other questions about the mounting
to explain better. If your bike is not red

column1: Cool.  And thank you for an intelligent response devoid of the silly
One of the basic things you need to
>have in a statistic to be able to predict a player's performance on it
>in the future is for there to be a correlation from year to year.  A
>player's batting average is correlated fairly well from year to year.
>the basic problems with something like clutch batting average - overall
>batting average is that the correlation from year to year is almost zero.
>Adding to the sample size doesn't seem to help much.

column2: I think the large-scale sample size is part of the problem.

column1: It seems to me that if we were to plot all the players in baseball
in regard to BA vs. Clutch BA deviation we would get some kind of
bell curve.  (The X-axis being the +/- deviation in clutch hitting
vs. non-clutch;  the Y-axis being the number of players.)  Certainly
there would be *some* players on the extreme ends of the bell.  My
*supposition* is that if we were to find the SAME players consistently
(year after year) at one end of the bell or the other
be able to make some reasonable conclusions about *those* players

column2: consider the following two players from 1984-1987:

column1: >               AB      H       BA              AB      H       BA
>If you had had these two players in 1988

column2: you'd bat Maldonado for Lemon in a blink of an eye.  Well
Maldonado hit .267 in non-clutch and .190 in clutch

column1: >hit .254 in non-clutch and .313 in clutch.  Before you accuse me of
You won't hear those kind of accusations from me.  It is interesting

column2: because he is someone whom I have also

column1: looked at.  He has been a very inconsistent hitter (in terms of BA)
been traded between leagues as well as clubs.  His clutch hitting

column2: for my purposes in 1993 I would

column1: not draw any conclusions about his ability to hit in the clutch based
on his prior performance.  I don't know how I would have felt in 1988
but you may indeed be right.
When I looked at Sabo I found a more consistent record of hitting
a more consistent pattern of his clutch hitting being proportionately
below his non-clutch BA.  Ditto for Joe Carter.
This probably brings us to the heart of the disagreement I am having
with others on this topic.  Must any conclusion based on statistical
history be able to be applied broadly throughout a data base before
it has any validity?  Is it impossible (or irrational) to apply
statistical analysis to selected components of the data base?

You are not alone.  My '79 Honda Accord with 110
I replaced the brake master cylinder myself.  It took about an hour and cost
about $45.  Sure beats paying $300 to have someone else do it!  If I wanted to
rebuild my own master cylinder instead of putting in a rebuilt one
have cost only $20 to $30 for the rebuild kit.
The Honda brake master cylinder is easy to get to.  Two bolts attach it to the
engine compartment.  Two brake lines enter the master cylinder.  The tricky
part was that the brake lines were stuck tight.  My Craftsmen open end wrench
rounded off the bolt heads!  I had to use Vise Grips to loosen those suckers.
Wow!  Best invention since sliced bread.  After that it was very easy.  Bolt
This is quite easy even for a beginner.  My local auto parts store had a repair
manual for the Honda Accord; it had detailed diagrams of the master brake
cylinder and a step-by-step procedure for replacing it.

> I need some advice on having someone ride pillion with me on my 750 Ninja.
> This will be the the first time I've taken anyone for an extended ride
> (read: farther than around the block  :-).  We'll be riding some twisty
> fairly bumpy roads (the Mines Road-Mt.Hamilton Loop for you SF Bay Areans).
An extended ride as a passenger on a 750 ninja.

column2: I hate to be a wet sock

column1: I was a passenger on many bikes for the longest time before I started

column2: and I grew to hate long rides on sport bikes.  The passenger

column1: seats are not designed for long rides.  The passenger positions aren't
even usually designed for short rides.  I ended up torturing my knees and my
back by taking long rides as a passenger on sport bikes.  One of the
reasons I originally liked my current guythingy so much was becase he had
I'd suggest a shorter extended ride at first -- a short turn in the mountains
or some such.  Then see how much pain she's in
The best advice I'd give a beginning passenger:
- Don't get on the bike until the rider says its OK
signal for the rider to tell you when its OK to get off.  After I get on
the bike I squeeze my riders hips to tell that I'm ready
he nods his head to show its OK for me to get off.
- Keep your feet on the pegs at all times.  Don't wiggle (unless your rider
- The best passengers are those which are unobtrusive.  Echo the movements
and lean of your rider.  Look over the shoulder thats most comfortable
but during turns look over the shoulder on the inside of the turn.
- Get used to your rider's shifting style (Riders:  use a reasonably
consistent shifting style).  Avoid helmet bonk.  Helmet bonk is
when your rider revs the bike up and then shifts and the sudden change
in foreward acceleration causes your helmet to bonk his/hers.  It

column2: put a hand or both hands on the tank to keep

column1: your weight from pushing your rider up onto the tank.  Putting your hands
on the tank is also a good way to stretch your back if you're in pain
but I'm told it gets harder to steer in turns if you leave them there.
- Switch your hands to the guardrail to stretch your shoulders
sure and squeeze your thighs while you're doing it so your rider knows you're
still there. :)  The guard rail isn't as safe as holding onto your rider.
- Don't be afraid to ask for frequent stops if you're in pain or
losing feeling in your feet.  Passenger seats are not generally designed
for comfort.  Work out some sort of pull over signal beforehand.

prospects and the relationship between age
Fame members? It was part of their preseason special. Basically
at players that had amassed 1000 plate appearances (or ABs) by the time they

column2: they found out such players comprised the majority of MVPs in

column1: the history of the game. They also found out such players represented the
majority of the players in the hall of fame. The kicker
they actually did some number-crunching and found that such players' careers
lasted much longer than the careers of players not in that group. They also
found that these players produced at both a greater level of performance and
produced over twice the raw totals (HRs
column2: etc) of the other players. The first

column1: group outhit the second something like .282 to .260 in raw BA
the second group in such categories as HRs
It was the most impressive thing I've seen on ESPN in recent memory.

column1: No. Not at all. The Viking was a trick little unit made way back when
(forties? fifties?) when Spag was trying to make a go of it in racing.
The first iteration (the Springer) was a boxer twin

column2: but with an overhead point cam (see below for

column1: more on the valvetrain). The problem was that the thing had no ground
clearance whatsoever. The solution was to curve the cylinder bores
that the ground clearance was substantially increased:

column2: except that the bores were gradually curved
as the pistons were loath to make a sharp-angled turn

column1: in the middle of their stroke. The engine also had curved connecting
The engine stuck out so far because of its revolutionary (and still
unique) overhead cam system. Through the use of clever valve timing and

column2: only a single cam lobe was

column1: required to drive both overhead valves.
Just as revolutionary was the hydraulic valve actuation
pressurized stream of oil to power the waterwheel which kept the lobe
spinning over. One side effect that required some rather brutal
engineering fixes was that until the engine's oil pressure came up to

column2: the engine's valve timing would be more or less random

column1: resulting in some impressive start-up valve damage. The solution was a
little hand crank that pressurized the cases before you started the

column2: remarkably similar to the system used in new Porsches to

column1: pressurize the oil system before the car is started (the cage
uses an electric oil pump. Wimps).

column2: the engine had a nasty propensity for explosively

column1: firing its valves into the pistons when a cylinder would temporarily
lose a bit of oil pressure in a corner. The solution was to run even
higher oil pressures and change the gaskets and seals regularly. This
was feasible because it was a racing engine.
With just a single overhead lobe

column2: the head of the engine came to an

column1: Note that the tip was not truly vertical
(it was at about a 70 degree angle to the

column2: and this drawing doesn't show the

column1: curvature because there was none in the
head itself. The bore curve would start
about where the cylinder bore disappears in
The effect of the pointy heads on top of a pair of gently (pundits of
the day even said sensuously) curved cylinders was much like a pair of
finned Viking horns poking out from beneath the gas tank. Thus
The Vik was a moderately successful racer

column2: but plagued by problems relating to its revolutionary
it was dumped when Spag finally realized that

column1: racing was not where the Spagthorpe name would be made. The machines
were raced for another year or two by privateers
Springers. Confusing the issue is one old Spag staffer who swears up and
down that this machine was tooled for production
twenty or thirty machines may have come off the line. However

column2: but here are my rules for traffic light survival:

column1: - I try to *never* stop just over a hill behind a car.  If I have
to stop in such a location
column2: I pull almost completely next to the

column1: car in front of me.  If I'm the only one (ie no car in front)
turn the bike somewhat sideways across the lane
visibility to any oncoming vehicle.  Make sure to keep your
white; turning sideways on a black bike might not be as beneficial.)

column2: I stop with a bit of room ahead of me (usually

column1: about two or three bike lengths).  This will (hopefully) give
me room to pull forward and to the side as a car approaches.
- If you are the last in a line of vehicles
*constantly!*  If you see a vehicle approaching
any evidence to indicate that he/she is slowing down
- Flicker your brake light.  If I'm the last vehicle in line
will pull and release the brake as a car approaches from
behind (noticed the car by watching my mirrors
I vary the speed of the flicker
column2: hoping to make the cager notice

column1: that there's something in the lane ahead of him.

column3: it's the situation where you are first in line

column1: that I feel most defenseless.  If you're first in line
route is seriously limited - you can only move forward to the extent that
you don't enter the intersection.  I leave some room behind the stop line

column2: the #@$*! light activators are always right up
and watch the mirrors.  I *think* I've decided

column1: that hopping off the bike might be the best way out of this situation.
